entry.title: Combined summary - Bitcoin-development Digest, Vol 48, Issue 63
entry.summary: The email thread discusses the implementation of WinterNitz one-time signatures and a Byzantine consensus system in Bitcoin. The use of these signatures would provide personal integrity to transactions and evaluate them through an intermediate proxy state. Another topic discussed is the upcoming feature and string freeze for Bitcoin core 0.11 planning. Thomas Voegtlin discusses long-term mining incentives and how Bitcoin derives its value from the assumption that a steady-state regime will be reached in the future. The debate over block size increase for Bitcoin has been ongoing, with concerns that increasing the block size will lead to centralization, security issues, and other technical problems. One proposal to address these issues is to develop off-chain infrastructure such as the Lightning Network. It is suggested that a clear vision is needed for the future of Bitcoin, including steady-state regime and incentives for miners once the subsidy is gone. Gavin Andresen believes that Bitcoin is an experiment but has the potential to succeed due to its incentives and hard-working people behind it.
